title: The Planet Vulcan: The Invisible or Spiritual Planet
subject: astrology; weston
description: An advertisement for H. L. Weston's astrology book, "The Planet Vulcan", one of several related books which established Vulcan's identity in 20th century astrology as an "esoteric" or spiritual planet, rather than an observable, physical one. This advertisement appeared in a pamplet by Weston's publisher, Llewellyn George, "Astrology, what it Is and What It Is Not."

title: How Planets Affect You: Philosophy of Planetary Vibrations
creator: Llewellyn George
subject: astrology
description: The astrologer-publisher Llewellyn George, after a passage on the recently discovered planet Pluto, here expresses as wish for astronomers to improve their methods and catch-up on the question of Vulcan. George believed that astrologers had discovered Pluto via perturbations in their own charts long before scientists did the same though George also expresses the sentiment that the processes were analagous.

title: Esoteric Astrology: A Study in Human Nature
creator: Alan Leo
subject: astrology; earth; neptune; sun
description: The astrologer Alan Leo assigns meaning to Vulcan without issue and notes that the number of planets in the solar system varies over history.

title: Star & Weather Gossip: Concerning the Heavens, the Atmosphere, the Sea
creator: Joseph Henry Elgie
subject: meteorology; mercury; leverrier; lescarbault; eclipse; sightings
description: A reprint of an article, taken from a self-published collection of the author's occasional columns in T.P. Weekly's, the Yorkshire post, and other British papers, a collection financed partly from advertisements of amateur astronomy equipment. Unlike the esoteric astrologer's of the early twentieth century, the author is quite convinced that the Vulcan fad has ended.

title: Astrology
creator: M. M. MacGregor
subject: astrology; mercury
description: Writing under a pseudonym, the astrologer Mabel Shoemaker calls Vulcan the "Genius of the Times", a symbol of the modern era's "Progressive Awakening Spirit." Though other astrologers sought confirmation from antiquity for the planet, for her the newness of the discovery appears to have influenced her interpretation of its symbolism.

title: The Book of the Damned
creator: Charles Fort
subject: philosophy; leverrier; lescarbault; sightings
description: For Charles Fort, the most interesting question is, "If Vulcan never existed, then how did so many astronomers see it, and why were their observations synchronized?" His answer relates to hypnotism and the non-rational nature of reality. Leverrier, himself hypnotized by selectively gathering data on Mercury, influenced others' perceptions through his enthusiasm. For Fort such cases of mass delusion are part of his theory-building upon the "damned" data that science refuses to incorporate.

title: The Scheme of Evolution on the Musical Scale
creator: Arthur E. Taylor
serial_title: Rays from the Rose Cross: A Magazine of Mystic Light, Vol 6, Issue 6
subject: astrology; religion; rosicrucianism; chart; sun; earth; moon; jupiter; venus; zodiac
description: Volumes 5-9 of the "Rays from the Rose Cross" make frequent reference to the Vulcan "period" or "stage," which its contributors connect the divine and the words of creation from Genesis. In this chart that incorporates astronomical bodies, the signs of the zodiac, and a Kabbalah-like assortment of layers stretching from the transcendent to the mundane and chemical. Vulcan, the rightmost heavenly body, is connected to the the "home" key of C and bridges the "Divine Spirit" with "Concrete Thought."

title: The New Planet Vulcan
subject: column;leverrier;lescarbault;sightings;wolf
description: One of many American newspaper columns based upon an article in the North British Review. The New York Observer's uncredited columnist presents a factual summary of the events and disagreement.

title: Literature: North British Review
subject: bulletin; leverrier; lescarbault; sightings
description: One of many American newspaper articles reporting on an article from the North British Review (here as a "literature" review), the anonymous journalist of the Metropolitan Record presents a vivid and dizzying account of Leverrier's fame in Paris.

title: The Red Planet Mars
subject: astronomy; column; mars; leverrier; lescarbault
description: Unlike some more breathless reports about Lescarbault's sighting of Vulcan, the author of this column on the science of Mars is reluctant to admit the new planet to the table.

title: Literature, Science, and Art
subject: bulletin; leverrier; lescarbault; sightings;
description: This Boston paper is one of the earliest American notices about Lescarbault's sighting, and even it notes the inadequacies inherent in the observation.

title: New Planets---Interesting Statements by M. Leverrier
subject: column; leverrier; mercury;
description: An early announcement of Leverrier's Vulcan hypothesis, before the planet received its name.

title: New Planets---Interesting Statements by M. Leverrier
New Planets---Interesting Statements by M. Leverrier
The Planet Mercury
subject: column; mercury; neptune
description: In April 1871, Mercury, Venus, Mars, and Jupiter were all visible in the early evening sky. After noting the rarity of so clear a view of Mercury with the naked eye, the Times author disparages the suggestion of Vulcan, a hypothesis now a decade old but seemingly a part of astronomical conversations.

title: Vulcan
subject: column; sightings; sunspots;
description: This 1873 New York Times column mentions a worldwide effort to predict and observe intra-Mercurial objects. Aside from this sighting in Shangai from 1873, the article mentions a debate between a Prof. Alexander of the National Academy and one Prof. Kirkwood as to whether one or multiple objects best fits the evidence.

title: The Planet Vulcan [Op-ed]
creator: H.E.P.
subject: letter; sightings;
description: A letter to the editor of the New York Times claiming that an amateur astronomer from upstate New York has spotted a planet crossing the sun's surface. Notably, this sighting reports a far-slower transit than four-hours observed by others.

title: The Discovery of Vulcan
subject: bulletin; watson; sightings;
description: Not to be outdone in the game of discovering asteroids, Ann Arbor's James C. Watson announced his sighting of Vulcan in 1878, following a solar eclipse. Watson expresses a hope that others will be able to confirm his sighting.

title: Seek to solve problem of an intra-Mercurial planet.
creator: Mary Proctor
subject: column; lick observatory; eclipses;
description: Another approaching solar eclipse raises the specter of intra-Mercurial objects again, but it seems the hope for Vulcan has long faded among the sun-gazers.

title: Seek to solve problem of an intra-Mercurial planet.
Seek to solve problem of an intra-Mercurial planet.
Seek to solve problem of an intra-Mercurial planet.
A plan or map of the Solar System projected for schools & academies
creator: Hall Colby
subject: astronomy; chart;
description: A chart of the solar system created for New York state schools and presented to the Library of Congress in October of 1846. Predating Leverrier's hypothesis, Colby was likely influenced by the French astronomer Jacques Babinet, who had made related conjectures the same year as this chart.

title: God's Glory in the Heavens
creator: Bill Leitch
subject: astronomy; religion;
description: Leitch, a theologian, emphasizes the difference between the famous scientist Leverrier and the humble country physician, Lescarbault. His telling includes anecdotes about the latter refusing equal honors in Paris's salons. Leitch finds interesting the confluence of these characters and their differing motivations, with respect to the understanding of creation.

title: A New Manual of the Elements of Astronomy, Descriptive and Mathematical...
creator: Henry Kiddle
subject: astronomy; lescarbault; leverrier; sightings;
description: In his manual for astronomy students, Kiddle feels the need to address the Vulcan question but finds nothing of scientific or philosophical importance to say on the subject. For him, it's a matter of contradictory evidence and not a question of theoretical trouble. His 1871 revision would find even less to say.

title: Fourteen Weeks in Descriptive Astronomy
creator: Joel Dorman Steele
subject: astronomy; leverrier; lescarbault; sightings;
description: Among figures and object lessons on the scale and motion of the solar system, Steele's introductory text includes Vulcan. Though he notes the controversy over Vulcan's existence, Steele seems perplexed by it. Like many others of the time period, he makes much of Lescarbault's country lifestyle.

title: Report of the Lick Observatory
creator: W. W. Campbell
publisher: Publications of the Astronomical Society of the Pacific, Vol. 21, No. 128
subject: astronomy; lick observatory; eclipse;
description: American astronomers based out of the University of California's Lick Observatory outside San Jose conclude that there is no Vulcan. The team used evidence from eclipses of the previous ten years.

title: On Some Astronomical Myths
creator: Richard A. Proctor
subject: astronomy; leverrier; sightings;
description: Proctor's lengthy article in the gentlemen's periodical, Belgravia, explains the unusual methods by which Vulcan was predicted. After reviewing the original tale of Leverrier meeting Lescarbault and Liais's objections to their announcement, Proctor works through the last fifteen years of searches. Here he also demonstrates the errors of one sighting in America.

title: Science Byways
creator: Richard A. Proctor
subject: astronomy; leverrier; meteors; sun;
description: Originally published in Cornhill Magazine this same year, Proctor's article considers a number of ways that Leverrir's observations on Mercury interact with recent observations on asteroids and developing ideas about the sun's source of heat. For astronomer's, Leverrier's calculations on Mercury's orbit remain a mystery worthy of explanation even if they've begun to reject the Vulcan hypothesis.

title: A Short History of Natural Science and of the Progress of Discovery
creator: Arabella B. Buckley
subject: astronomy; leverrier; adams; neptune; herschel; uranus;
description: Buckley recounts the story of Leverrier's discovery of Neptune through mathematics for younger readers. No mention of Vulcan is made in the tale of science heroism.

title: Discovery of Vulcan
creator: Lewis Swift
subject: astronomy'sightings;swift;
description: Breathlessly, Lewis Swift recounts his observation of a intra-Mercurial transit in the pages of the astronomical journal, Science Observer. Swift's was one of many sightings which revived interest in the Vulcan hypothesis in 1878.

title: The Comic Liar: A Book Not Commonly Found in Sunday Schools
creator: W. L. Alden
subject: humor; column;
description: Newspaper humorist Alden complains about the frequency of Vulcan stories then presents a comical take on the life of some typical workdays on the planet.

title: Astronomy: A Simple Introduction to a Noble Science
creator: Edmund Neison
subject: astronomy;
description: Edmund Nelson's introductory text explores some means by which Vulcan might be seen while giving figures of the necessary size and brightness of such an object. Given the lack of consistent sightings of such large objects, he concludes that several smaller objects are more likely.

title: A Text-Book of General Astronomy for Colleges and Scientific Schools
creator: Charles A. Young
subject: astronomy; lescarbault; sightings; eclipse;
description: Young recounts the problems of Mercury in this introductory text, and he explores the possibilities of a single planet or several smaller bodies. Young goes on to consider the merits of Michigan's James Watson's observation ten years earlier.

title: The Science-History of the Universe, Vol. 1
creator: Francis Rolt-Wheeler
subject: astronomy; leverrier
description: In this introductory text, Rolt-Wheeler discuesses Vulcan alongside the possibility of still-other unsighted planets, but ultimately the author dismisses Vulcan as an improbability.
